pitrou commented on a change in pull request #11624:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11624#discussion_r744974763



##########
File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_table.py
##########
@@ -1746,3 +1746,29 @@ def test_table_select():
     result = table.select(['f2'])
     expected = pa.table([a2], ['f2'])
     assert result.equals(expected)
+
+
+def test_table_group_by():
+    table = pa.table([
+        pa.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
+        pa.array(["a", "a", "b", "b", "c"]),
+    ], names=["values", "keys"])
+
+    r = table.group_by("keys", ["values"], "hash_sum")

Review comment:
       Should we hide the "hash_" prefix as an implementation detail? @lidavidm @jorisvandenbossche 




--

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11624#discussion_r744994425

##########
@@ -1746,3 +1746,29 @@ def test_table_select():
     result = table.select(['f2'])

     assert result.equals(expected)
+
+
+def test_table_group_by():
+    table = pa.table([
+        pa.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
+        pa.array(["a", "a", "b", "b", "c"]),
+    ], names=["values", "keys"])
+

       Hmm, we do document the "hash_" prefix in the API docs (though I suppose those are the C++ docs anyways). But I would prefer to hide it since it's redundant. (How will we do the documentation on the Python side though?)

pitrou commented on a change in pull request #11624:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11624#discussion_r746700050



##########
File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_table.py
##########
@@ -1746,3 +1746,48 @@ def test_table_select():
     result = table.select(['f2'])
     expected = pa.table([a2], ['f2'])
     assert result.equals(expected)
+
+
+def test_table_group_by():
+    table = pa.table([
+        pa.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
+        pa.array(["a", "a", "b", "b", "c"]),
+    ], names=["values", "keys"])
+
+    r = table.group_by("keys", ["values"], "hash_sum")
+    assert r.to_pydict() == {
+        "key_0": ["a", "b", "c"],
+        "sum": [3, 7, 5]
+    }
+
+    r = table.group_by("keys", ["values", "values"], [
+                       "hash_sum", "hash_count"])
+    assert r.to_pydict() == {
+        "key_0": ["a", "b", "c"],
+        "sum": [3, 7, 5],
+        "count": [2, 2, 1]
+    }
+
+    # Test without hash_ prefix

Review comment:
       Does it make sense to allow both?




--

@@ -1746,3 +1746,48 @@ def test_table_select():

+def test_table_group_by():

amol- commented on a change in pull request #11624:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11624#discussion_r746782346



##########
File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_table.py
##########
@@ -1746,3 +1746,48 @@ def test_table_select():
     result = table.select(['f2'])
     expected = pa.table([a2], ['f2'])
     assert result.equals(expected)
+
+
+def test_table_group_by():
+    table = pa.table([
+        pa.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
+        pa.array(["a", "a", "b", "b", "c"]),
+    ], names=["values", "keys"])
+
+    r = table.group_by("keys", ["values"], "hash_sum")
+    assert r.to_pydict() == {
+        "key_0": ["a", "b", "c"],
+        "sum": [3, 7, 5]
+    }
+
+    r = table.group_by("keys", ["values", "values"], [
+                       "hash_sum", "hash_count"])
+    assert r.to_pydict() == {
+        "key_0": ["a", "b", "c"],
+        "sum": [3, 7, 5],
+        "count": [2, 2, 1]
+    }

Review comment:
       You would get columns with duplicate names (two `sum` columns). At that point it would be hard to tell what they refer to. I did an improvement in https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11624/commits/30b64fe45bc3318ab59ad39194b5a5a12226aba9 where column names are named after the column they refer to, so if you are asking two sums for two different columns you would get `col1_sum` and `col2_sum` making obvious what they refer to.




--

##########
File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_table.py
##########
@@ -1746,3 +1746,48 @@ def test_table_select():
     result = table.select(['f2'])
     expected = pa.table([a2], ['f2'])
     assert result.equals(expected)
+
+
+def test_table_group_by():
+    table = pa.table([
+        pa.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
+        pa.array(["a", "a", "b", "b", "c"]),
+    ], names=["values", "keys"])
+
+    r = table.group_by("keys", ["values"], "hash_sum")
+    assert r.to_pydict() == {
+        "key_0": ["a", "b", "c"],

+

Review comment:
       I felt it made a bit more clear the relationship with compute functions names. The documentation will explain that, but being able to pass the compute function name as is makes it a bit more explicit.




--

pitrou commented on a change in pull request #11624:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11624#discussion_r748340089



##########
File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_table.py
##########
@@ -1746,3 +1746,56 @@ def test_table_select():
     result = table.select(['f2'])
     expected = pa.table([a2], ['f2'])
     assert result.equals(expected)
+
+
+def test_table_group_by():
+    table = pa.table([
+        pa.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
+        pa.array(["a", "a", "b", "b", "c"]),
+        pa.array([10, 20, 30, 40, 50])
+    ], names=["values", "keys", "bigvalues"])
+
+    r = table.group_by("keys", ["values"], "hash_sum")
+    assert r.to_pydict() == {
+        "key": ["a", "b", "c"],
+        "values_sum": [3, 7, 5]
+    }

Review comment:
       You should probably sort the results so that it's not dependent on underlying implementation details.




--

amol- commented on a change in pull request #11624:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11624#discussion_r748397868



##########
File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_table.py
##########
@@ -1746,3 +1746,56 @@ def test_table_select():
     result = table.select(['f2'])
     expected = pa.table([a2], ['f2'])
     assert result.equals(expected)
+
+
+def test_table_group_by():
+    table = pa.table([
+        pa.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
+        pa.array(["a", "a", "b", "b", "c"]),
+        pa.array([10, 20, 30, 40, 50])
+    ], names=["values", "keys", "bigvalues"])
+
+    r = table.group_by("keys", ["values"], "hash_sum")
+    assert r.to_pydict() == {
+        "key": ["a", "b", "c"],
+        "values_sum": [3, 7, 5]
+    }

Review comment:
       Isn't that something the test would catch if it ever changes? You would end up with the values for the key into the aggregation result and viceversa if the order of the columns we emit ever changes.
   
   I added a test case where the aggregations are reversed and it still passes, at the moment the function always output the aggregations in the order you provided them.




--

pitrou commented on a change in pull request #11624:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11624#discussion_r748415148



##########
File path: python/pyarrow/tests/test_table.py
##########
@@ -1746,3 +1746,56 @@ def test_table_select():
     result = table.select(['f2'])
     expected = pa.table([a2], ['f2'])
     assert result.equals(expected)
+
+
+def test_table_group_by():
+    table = pa.table([
+        pa.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
+        pa.array(["a", "a", "b", "b", "c"]),
+        pa.array([10, 20, 30, 40, 50])
+    ], names=["values", "keys", "bigvalues"])
+
+    r = table.group_by("keys", ["values"], "hash_sum")
+    assert r.to_pydict() == {
+        "key": ["a", "b", "c"],
+        "values_sum": [3, 7, 5]
+    }

Review comment:
       I mean the result is currently:
   ```python
       {
           "key": ["a", "b", "c"],
           "values_sum": [3, 7, 5]
       }
   ```
   
   but it could very well be:
   ```python
       {
           "key": ["a", "c", "b"],
           "values_sum": [3, 5, 7]
       }
   ```
   
   or any other order




--

fields.summary: [Python] Provide access to hash_aggregate functions through a group_by method

comments.body: This ticket is closed so I created new one: ARROW-18137
